.. Places parent toc into the sidebar

:parenttoc: True

.. include:: ../../includes/big_toc_css.rst

======================================
Exploratory Analysis
======================================

PiML supports three types of plots for exploratory analysis:  univariate plots, bivariate plots, and multivariate plots.



Univariate Plots
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
We use different plots for numerical features and categorical features.

For numerical features, we show density and histogram chart:

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='univariate', uni_feature='cnt')

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_001.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left

For categorical features, we show the bar chart that displays the frequency of values.

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='univariate', uni_feature='yr')

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_002.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left



Bivariate Plots
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

The bivariate plot is a graphical representation that displays the relationship between two variables.
We use three types of charts for different combinations of feature types.

For numerical & numerical, we use the scatter plot to show the relationship between two variables as a collection of points on a two-dimensional graph.

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='bivariate', bi_features=['temp', 'cnt'])

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_003.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left
   
If the pair is numerical & categorical, we use the box plot to show the relationship by displaying the numerical feature distribution conditional on each category of categorical feature.

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='bivariate', bi_features=['hr', 'season'])

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_004.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left

If the pair is categorical & categorical, we use the stack bar plot, each bar represents a category in one variable and is divided into segments representing the frequency of the second variable within that category. 

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='bivariate', bi_features=['yr', 'season'])

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_005.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left



Multivariate Plots
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
There are two types of multivariate charts in PiML: correlation heatmap, and correlation graph. Both the correlation heatmap and correlation graph display  pairwisePearson correlations, using different representations. 


Here is an example of the correlation heatmap:

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='multivariate', multi_type='correlation_heatmap')

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_006.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left

Here is an example of the correlation graph:

.. jupyter-input::

    exp.eda(show='multivariate', multi_type='correlation_graph')

.. figure:: ../../auto_examples/data/images/sphx_glr_plot_2_data_eda_007.png
   :target: ../../auto_examples/data/plot_2_data_eda.html
   :align: left



Examples
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

The full example codes of this section can be found in the following link.

.. topic:: Example

    * :ref:`sphx_glr_auto_examples_data_plot_2_data_eda.py`
